general: This law makes sure that the government's spending plans are responsible, meaning they should not spend more than they have. It also creates an office to check if the government's finances are correct and publishes reports on how much money the government has and how it is being spent. This helps ensure that the government is using taxpayers' money wisely and making good financial decisions.

series.short: "Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act: Treasury Charter and OBR Functions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act of 2011 requires the Treasury to create a charter outlining their budget responsibilities and objectives.
* Simplified point 2: The charter must include the Treasury's fiscal mandate, which outlines how they plan to achieve their objectives, as well as matters to be included in a financial statement and budget report.
* Simplified point 3: The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) will examine and report on the sustainability of the public finances, and provide forecasts and analyses of the economy and public finances.
* Simplified point 4: The OBR must perform its duty objectively, transparently, and impartially, and take into account government policies that are relevant to its performance.
* Simplified point 5: The charter can include guidance on how the OBR should perform its duty, but cannot specify the methods used to make forecasts, assessments, or analyses.
* Simplified point 6: The OBR must aim to carry out its functions efficiently and cost-effectively, and must publish its reports and send them to the Treasury and Parliament.
* Simplified point 7: The OBR has a right of access to all government information that it may reasonably require for the purpose of performing its duty, and can require assistance or explanations from anyone holding or accountable for that information.

series.short: "The Role of the Comptroller and Auditor General in Overseeing Public Spending in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The National Audit Act 2011 establishes the role of the Comptroller and Auditor General (C&AG) as the head of the National Audit Office (NAO) responsible for auditing public spending in the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The C&AG is appointed by the Queen on the recommendation of the Prime Minister, and must have the agreement of the Chairman of the Committee of Public Accounts.
* Simplified point 3: The C&AG's duties include conducting audits of government departments, reporting on the accounts of the public sector, and providing independent assurance of the accuracy and reliability of public finances.
* Simplified point 4: The C&AG is prohibited from being a member of the House of Lords, and cannot hold any other office or position that might create a conflict of interest.
* Simplified point 5: Remuneration arrangements for the C&AG are made jointly by the Prime Minister and the Chairman of the Committee of Public Accounts, and the C&AG is subject to annual parliamentary scrutiny of their expenses.
* Simplified point 6: The C&AG can only resign or be removed by the Queen on the address of both Houses of Parliament.

series.short: Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act 2011: Empowering the Treasury for Smooth Transition
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act 2011 gives the Treasury the power to make changes to existing laws through orders called "statutory instruments" if necessary to implement the act's provisions.
* Simplified point 2: These orders can include supplementary, incidental, transitional, transitory, or saving provisions to ensure a smooth transition to the new budget responsibility and audit requirements.
* Simplified point 3: The orders made by the Treasury can amend or revoke existing subordinate legislation made before the last day of the session in which the act was passed.
* Simplified point 4: The commencement of the act's provisions will be staggered, with some parts coming into force immediately after royal assent, while others will be brought into force later by statutory instrument made by the Treasury.
* Simplified point 5: The act applies to England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, and any amendments or repeals of existing enactments will have the same extent as the original enactments.

summary:
The Budget Responsibility and National Audit Act of 2011 is a law that helps the Treasury make sure it's managing the country's money well. It does this by making the Treasury create a document called a "charter" that explains what it wants to do and how it plans to do it. This charter includes things like the Treasury's goals and how it plans to reach them.
The law also creates a group called the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), which checks to see if the Treasury's plans are good for the country's finances. The OBR looks at things like how much money the government has, how much it spends, and whether it's likely to have enough money in the future.
The OBR also has to follow certain rules, like being objective and transparent, and taking into account any important government policies. The OBR then sends its findings to the Treasury and Parliament so everyone can see what it found.
Additionally, the law sets up the role of the Comptroller and Auditor General (C&AG), who oversees public spending in the UK. They make sure that government departments are spending their money wisely and accurately report on the public finances.
Finally, the law allows the Treasury to make changes to existing laws through orders called "statutory instruments" if necessary to implement the act's provisions. This ensures a smooth transition to the new budget responsibility and audit requirements.
